documents.document: RT @robinmarceline: abled people: "disabled folks who need disposable plastic straws to drink safely should just buy their own & take themâ€¦

So yeah, at least itâ€™s not fractured. To be honest I kinda already knew ballet had done some strange things to my toes and feet, but in a way itâ€™s good to have that confirmed. Just need to ice the foot, get arch support insoles and wear supportive shoes.

Was at the docâ€™s today, told her my left footâ€™s been sore for a few weeks. She had a look, said I was flat-footed, which I was not when I was a kid. Then she said I had very strangely shaped ankles. I told her I did a lot of ballet when I was younger, she was like https://t.co/l8IOr1v1qN

@KLM Please get in touch with @PriscillaOno and help her find her luggage as soon as possible. You losing her bags could mean her losing part of her livelihood, equipment she has spent many years and a lot of money amassing as she built her career. Some of it irreplaceable.
@sarahhollowell You absolute beauty, you!

Had some wonderful times with my mum, dad, sister, brother-in-law and my ex-step-mum (itâ€™s complicated lol) and her boyfriend. Just a wonderful holiday with the worst ending possible. Anyway, Iâ€™ll stop now cos Iâ€™m so hungry I could eat a vegetarian horse. Just needed to vent.

Then we went down south to TÃ¸nsberg where we spent most of our time at the beach, it was almost too hot. I hadnâ€™t seen my niece and nephew for a year, and theyâ€™ve both grown so much, it was amazing to see them again.

I have to add that we had an absolutely wonderful time with my family in Norway until this happened. We went to see my grandparents in Trondheim for their combined 155th birthday, it was Robinâ€™s first time in Trondheim and I hadnâ€™t been there in 10 years.
Now to eat, maybe cry a bit more, and then sleep for about a week.

Robin was probably in even more pain than me, but he copes a bit better with 4 hours sleep than I do. The whole thing was an absolute farse. We were lucky to be surrounded by some incredibly understanding and helpful passengers in the same travel situation.

I legitimately canâ€™t remember the last time I have been this exhausted and in as much pain, and thatâ€™s saying something. We were put up at a hotel last night, when we finally got there at 10.30 pm, 11 hours after we got to the airport, I just sat and cried for 10 minutes.

After having been subjected to what I have no qualms about describing as physical and emotional torture for approx 22 hours by Norwegian Airline, Robin and I are finally home. It is nothing short of miraculous that we made it.
@muslimah_han For sure yes

@fromsarahlex So much this. Seeing me out on one of my good days does not negate my illness or my days in pure agony and complete exhaustion.

Iâ€™ve been a fan of Phil Elverum for ages. Iâ€™m so happy for him and Michelle Williams. I hope theyâ€™re truly happy together & wish them all the best in the future. (Also pls come to Edinburgh to play, Phil. Scotland needs your music.)
@ccstreeter Harold & Maude. The Straight Story.

@chronicbonbon White, cishet, access to healthcare thatâ€™s free at point of use, poor af but have parents who help, and Iâ€™d argue not only that geographical privilege is a thing, but that I most certainly have it. Fat but hourglass-shaped, which makes things a bit less awful.

@timbolton1 Someone once told me something fascinating, sounds fake to me so donâ€™t ask for a source, but apparently itâ€™s possible to enjoy intellectual pursuits AND enjoy light entertainment? I believe they said the two were â€œnot mutually exclusiveâ€? Probably bollocks though.

@HisRNwife @punnysamosa I donâ€™t have kids but I try my hardest to do this with my niece and nephew, no matter how seemingly small the issue. Itâ€™s incredible how much an apology can matter to a child, if you donâ€™t apologise, they can hold on to that for yeeeaaars. I speak from experience.
RT @HisRNwife: Apologize to your children when you lose your cool. They donâ€™t understand why youâ€™re upset and they deserve an explanation aâ€¦

@CbnLarissa so that wasnâ€™t a problem. The accent in Edinburgh isnâ€™t difficult to understand, but I did struggle a bit in the beginning with understanding people from Glasgow and the north of Scotland. Now I understand them fine, and people tell me I now have a Scottish accent myself.

@CbnLarissa After I finished school I just wanted to move to a different environment and experience something and someplace new. A friend was starting art college here so I figured I might as well go with her to Scotland, even though I had never been here before. I spoke English pretty well,
@CbnLarissa Iâ€™m Norwegian. I had to use google translate to understand your question, lol. Iâ€™ve been to Portugal but I didnâ€™t pick up the language (except a few swear words lol)

If youâ€™re abled, you donâ€™t get to decide whatâ€™s ableist. LISTEN to marginalised people. https://t.co/a2FcuFue54

@tentacles_blue @JayneKayleah @GateauxAmmo @Zero_Burn_ @ToniQueene Thanks for the apology. Sometimes people use words they donâ€™t realise are harmful, thatâ€™s understandable. My issue is with abled ppl telling disabled ppl to get over it or that itâ€™s not harmful when it doesnâ€™t affect them, ie doing the opposite of what the original tweet says.

@JayneKayleah @tentacles_blue @Zero_Burn_ @ToniQueene Or try to change it, which is what many disabled people are trying to do. But instead of listenting to them or the reasons why, youâ€™re speaking over them & telling them to get over it when you have no idea how it feels. Literally the opposite of what the original tweet says.

@JayneKayleah @GateauxAmmo @tentacles_blue @Zero_Burn_ @ToniQueene If someone breaks my nose with a Frisbee, OF COURSE Iâ€™m going to be mad about it, they obviously didnâ€™t mean to do it, but Iâ€™m still standing there with a broken nose and Iâ€™m expected to take that with a smile because they didnâ€™t intend to hurt me? Gtfoh

@JayneKayleah @GateauxAmmo @tentacles_blue @Zero_Burn_ @ToniQueene Just because the intentions are good does not mean the harm isnâ€™t done. Itâ€™s okay to be frustrated or hurt or pissed off when someone harms you, it is perfectly natural, and it SHOULD be perfectly natural to apologise you cause harm, instead of getting defensive.

@JayneKayleah @GateauxAmmo @tentacles_blue @Zero_Burn_ @ToniQueene the person bleeding and say â€œactually I donâ€™t need to apologise and try to do better in future cos I never intended to hit you in the faceâ€. When something causes harm, intent becomes irrelevant. The decent thing is to take it on board and try to do better, not get defensive.

@JayneKayleah @GateauxAmmo @tentacles_blue @Zero_Burn_ @ToniQueene Intent doesnâ€™t matter if the impact is causing harm. If Iâ€™m in a park throwing a frisbee with a friend and accidentally throw the frisbee in their face to the point that they start bleeding, the right thing for me to do is apologise and try to aim better in future, not go up to
RT @MKGenest: I know I'm an asshole for wanting everyone to have healthcare, an affordable education, a living wage, be treated equally, &â€¦

@JayneKayleah @GateauxAmmo @tentacles_blue @Zero_Burn_ @ToniQueene Itâ€™s the fact that itâ€™s used as a synonym for those things that makes it ableist. Same with â€œtone deafâ€, â€œdumbâ€ etc. The English language is absolutely filled with ableist terms, and for you to tell disabled people what is or isnâ€™t ableist under THIS of all tweets is unbelievable

@Imani_Barbarin I canâ€™t believe you had to have this argument under that tweet, and that the people who disagreed with you agreed with the first tweet. How do they not see the incompatability with telling a disabled person a word is not ableist but listening to other marginalised groups?

@dianasaladpot Ugh that sucks, Iâ€™m so sorry. Try to do something you enjoy and helps you relax and eat the food in good conscience. You had no way of knowing it would be cancelled, so try not to beat yourself up about it.
@mmannie123 @DexInept @markedly Thanks. It was incredibly stressful, but I have a good GP now which just makes things so much easier. Hopefully those experiences will stay in the past.

@DexInept @mmannie123 @markedly the worst thing has by far been their reaction and attitude to discovering that they were wrong and a patient (me) was right. I have been yelled at and treated like dirt because they didnâ€™t like being proven wrong. Trust me, I never went back to see them again.

@DexInept @mmannie123 @markedly Definitely, Iâ€™m not a confrontational person so Iâ€™ve been in tears when things like this has happened to me. The worst part for me has not been that the doctors were wrong, I donâ€™t expect every doctor to know the difference between every single brand name for different meds,

@DexInept @mmannie123 @markedly surgery was left off the chart. Idiotic. I also ended up in hospital once after a doctor decided a medication I had used for years didnâ€™t need to be reduced before I came off it completely, I could just suddenly stop and be fine. I was not.

@DexInept @mmannie123 @markedly wouldnâ€™t let up, he insisted my neighbour had never had heart surgery. As if thatâ€™s something you make up or forget? Our neighbour had to take his shirt off to show the scar. Still, the doctor insisted the scar could be from something else. Turned out the page about his heart

@DexInept @mmannie123 @markedly the isolation room he was supposed to stay in in order to track the doctor down to ensure he wouldnâ€™t be given the wrong medication. Several others like that. Our neighbour once went to a cardiologist who refused to believe he (our neighbour) had had heart surgery. The doctor

@DexInept @mmannie123 @markedly medications work and why I would end up in hospital if I used it. My partner once had an argument with a doctor about meds, the doc thought it was two different types, my partner tried to explain they were just different brand names for same medication. My partner had to leave

@DexInept @mmannie123 @markedly One doctor tried to prescribe me a cream containing diclofenac. Iâ€™m intolerant to diclofenac and told him so. He said it wouldnâ€™t be a problem because it was topical, not oral. I had to explain that topical medications are still absorbed into the bloodstream, which is why topical

@nestli @chronic_spoonie Very litte unfortuately. @csodacsirke @yrfatfriend Itâ€™s the worst. I just tried to remind myself that however bad I felt in that moment, it doesnâ€™t compare to how POC must feel facing those situations on the regular.

@beckybarnesblog Youâ€™ve done the best you can, but he hasnâ€™t let you in. Either bringing this up will make him reevaluate and let you in, or you decide to move on apart. Either way, youâ€™ve done all you can, but I realise it doesnâ€™t feel good right now xx

@itsmommy2u @TeenyTwoTimes Same thing here. Rheumatology has such a big waitlist they donâ€™t have the capacity to see patients they canâ€™t treat, and my suspected fibro/cfs canâ€™t be treated by rheum. 10 years without diagnosis. So frustrating.

@TeenyTwoTimes That sucks, but you should go. If you donâ€™t, who knows how long youâ€™ll have to wait till next time. I canâ€™t get an appointment with rheum even for diagnosis cos they donâ€™t have the capacity to see patients they canâ€™t treat, and they canâ€™t treat fibro/cfs. It bites.

@yrfatfriend I wanted to run after her and explain that I was just moving it to give her a seat, but I didnâ€™t cos I realised that chasing after her would only make myself feel better, not her, as she found another seat with some other friends. Anyway. Your thread just reminded me of it.

@yrfatfriend The third member looked at me funny before walking away, and only then I realised that to her, the choir member, it could have looked like I was moving my things because I was worried the â€œblack people would steal my stuffâ€. I was mortified at the realisation.
